channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: U.S. vaccine advisers end decades-long recommendation for all babies to get a hepatitis B shot at birth
item.description: Several medical societies and state health departments said they would continue to recommend them.

item.title: Benin Coup Attempt to Oust Talon Has Been Foiled, Interior Minister Says
item.description: The country’s interior minister said the situation was under control after a “small group of soldiers launched a mutiny,” but the president had yet to...

item.title: Inside the Fortune 500 CEO pressure cooker: surviving is harder than ever and requires an ‘odd combination’ of traits
item.description: Mark Thompson is a top CEO coach and Byron Loflin is Nasdaq's in-house board whisperer. They told Fortune about joining forces for "CEO Ready."

item.title: How Stablecoins Can Help Criminals Launder Money and Evade Sanctions
item.description: Through layers of intermediaries, stablecoins can be moved, swapped and mixed into pools of other funds in ways that are difficult to trace, experts s...

item.title: Your Gift Dilemmas, Solved
item.description: An expert from Wirecutter helps Morning readers with their trickiest holiday gift searches.

item.title: Following in Paul Newman and Yvon Chouinard’s footsteps: There are more ways for leaders to give it away in ‘the Great Boomer Fire Sale’ than ever
item.description: As the president and CEO of Newman's Own, which gives away 100% of its profits, I am hearing from more and more business owners who want to try.

item.title: Can We Stop Our Digital Selves From Becoming Who We Are?
item.description: Pay attention to how you pay attention.

item.title: Supreme Court to reconsider a 90-year-old unanimous ruling that limits presidential power on removing heads of independent agencies
item.description: The court's conservatives, liberal Justice Elena Kagan noted in September, seem to be “raring to take that action.”

item.title: So much of crypto is not even real—but that’s starting to change
item.description: Crypto has long felt like a giant casino with imaginary chips, but big recent breakthroughs mean it's fast becoming part of the real economy.

item.title: Presidential Power Gets Tested Before Supreme Court After Long Conservative Project to Shrink Agencies
item.description: President Trump has repeatedly ousted leaders of independent agencies despite federal laws meant to shield those regulators from politics.

item.title: Benin Coup Attempt to Oust Talon Has Been Foiled, Interior Minister Says
item.description: The country’s interior minister said the situation was under control after a “small group of soldiers launched a mutiny,” but the president had yet to...

item.title: Hong Kong Holds Vote as Officials Move Against ‘Anti-China’ Elements
item.description: The government is pushing hard to raise turnout in an election overshadowed by a deadly fire and public anger over safety lapses and official accounta...

item.title: Heathrow Airport Is Briefly Locked Down After Spray Is Used in Altercation
item.description: One man was arrested after a substance that appeared to be pepper spray was used during a fight in one of the airport’s parking garages, the police sa...

item.title: This Nebraska Prison Rehabilitated Inmates. Until ICE Paid to Fill It With Immigrants.
item.description: Over two decades, a minimum-security prison aimed at helping inmates prepare to leave prison was a point of civic pride. Now, state officials have con...

item.title: Martin Parr, Who Photographed Britain’s Unvarnished Quirks, Dies at 73
item.description: Mr. Parr trademarked a hyperrealism in his photography that illuminated the “craziness of the English,” making small details loom larger than life.
